results.title: Desert Air Force
results.creator_credit: Philip Dorte, Kenneth Rick and BBC Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “War in the Air”.
The air defence of the Middle East from Italy’s‘ entry into the war in Summer 1940 to the establishment of an advance wing of the Desert Air Force in Tripoli at the end of 1942.

results.title: The Great War
results.creator_credit: Alan Anderson, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “War Experience”.
Uses contemporary film records of the Australian forces in the 1914-18 War to illustrate the conditions in which they served and the effects on survivors.

results.title: The Australian airman: 1939-1945
results.creator_credit: Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “War Experience”.
The men who served in the Royal Australian Air Force during the Second World War. At first it was a European war - over Germany, France, and Italy, but then the allies were driven back over North Africa. The Japanese aggression brought the men back to Australian shores and Pacific islands. Joining the Air Force with a spirit of adventure, the close of the war saw broken spirits and mental and physical suffering.

results.creator_credit: Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “War Experience”.
Uses actual newsreel footage to record the Australian soldier’s participation in the Second World War. Covers fighting in Libya, Greece, Crete, Syria and Tripoli, and the Singapore, New Guinea and Borneo campaigns.

group_works.title: The Impact of the Second World War on Indonesian nationalism

results.title: The Impact of the Second World War on Indonesian nationalism
results.brief_description:
Episode number 14 of Series “War and society”.
The film shows how the Japanese encouraged Indonesian nationalism under the Japanese scheme for Greater Asia. Introduced by Donald Watt.

results.title: The road to total war
results.creator_credit: Barbara Sears and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “War”.
From Napoleon to Nagasaki, Gwynne Dyer charts how the major social, economic and technical developments of the last two hundred years have changed the methods and impact of modern warfare to lead us to the brink of total destruction. He guides the viewer through two centuries of world military history, recounting anecdotes and describing in vivid detail significant and sometimes little known events from past wars.

results.title: Goodbye war
results.creator_credit: Donna Dudinsky, Barbara Sears, Judith Merritt and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “War”.
For centuries the international system of states has settled questions of power, territory, national pride and sovereignty with military force. At any given time there are about twenty wars being waged in the international neighbourhood, and in all of them, the people have a particular goal they want to achieve, a goal which they believe outweighs the cost of war. Dyer looks at a number of recent examples. He also examines the efforts of citizens’ peace movements in Europe, in the USA and in the Soviet Union. He suggests that we must find an alternative to war if the planet is to survive.

results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “War”.
